overview_of_class: Big data is currency, to those initiated in the nuts and bolts of data science. This data literacy course introduces research on cultural markets, superstars, social media, and crowdsourcing, and provides you with tools to apply this research. You will learn how to plot and interpret graphs to measure performance in a cultural market; use Internet search data and Twitter conversations to forecast trends; build, visualize, and analyze networks; and to train machine learning algorithms for prediction. Except an open mind, there are no prerequisites for the class. While formal thinking is encouraged, the course focuses on providing conceptual foundations and hands-on tools that apply across a variety of fields in communication, computer science, economics, life sciences, and sociology.

subject: COMM_ST

overview_of_class: This course is an introduction to what strategic communication is, how it has evolved over time, and how to be successful in using strategic communication methods. Previously, organizational communication stood alone, and other separate organizational fields, such as public relations and marketing existed in a silo. In all of these areas, communication was studied separately and exclusively within limited contexts. Today, strategic communication has evolved due to our use of technology. The way we currently interact has changed how organizations are viewed, studied, and operated within; organizations have become boundary-less. In this course, we will examine organizational theories, processes, and practices that maintain and further strategic communication. A main focus will be the identification, examination, and assessment of stakeholders, both internal and external. Students will also explore organizational change and the practices that help to innovate, as well as challenges involved with management. We will start the course by gaining knowledge about strategic communication, and then we will start to apply it through real-world cases. At the end of this course, students will be able to understand, interact, assess, and communicate effectively within a variety of organizations by using strategic communication methods. This course is the foundational course for the strategic and organizational communication module in the Communication Studies department.

subject: COMM_ST

overview_of_class: Tom Erickson, a well-known researcher at IBM, has said that, in the near future, he expects maps to be as important to the future of the computing experience as the GUI is today. At the same time, more and more data science projects require knowledge of the unique properties of spatial data and experience with special tools for processing spatial data. This course will provide students with the necessary theory and applied knowledge to succeed in an increasingly "geo" world of computing and data science. The course will have a major group project component. For students interested in the private sector, the project will involve the either (1) conception and/or development of a location-aware technology (e.g. app) that they can add to their portfolio or (2) an applied spatial data science project. For those in or interested in graduate school, the project will consist of the conception and execution of a spatial computing or spatial data science research project.
